data.text:
Nancy Um | Patty Chang & David Kelley | Elizabeth DeLoughrey

with

Marisol Villela Balderrama | Abigail Berry | Carolyn Hauk

Elizabeth Keto | Noah Michaud | Johanna Middleton

Hande Sever | Shariq Shah | Xinyi Wei

NANCY UM is Associate Director for Research and Knowledge Creation at the Getty Research Institute. In this role, she oversees the research agendas of the GRI, including its international scholars program and digital initiatives. Her research explores the Islamic world from the perspective of the coast, with a focus on material, visual, and built culture on the Arabian Peninsula and around the rims of the Red Sea and the Indian Ocean. She is the author of The Merchant Houses of Mocha: Trade and Architecture in an Indian Ocean Port (Seattle: University of Washington Press, 2009) and Shipped but not Sold: Material Culture and the Social Protocols of Trade during Yemen’s Age of Coffee (Honolulu: University of Hawai’i Press, 2017), in addition to studies about trade, art, diplomacy, and gift exchange around the early modern Indian Ocean rim. From 2019 to 2022, she served as Associate Dean for Faculty Development and Inclusion in Harpur College at Binghamton University, where she established faculty mentoring and advancement programs, developed equitable hiring and retention initiatives, and spearheaded a new interdisciplinary minor in Digital and Data Studies.

PATTY CHANG is a Los Angeles based artist and educator who uses performance, video, installation and narrative forms when considering identity, gender, transnationalism, colonial legacies, the environment, large-scale infrastructural projects and impacted subjectivities. Her most recent collaborative project, Learning Endings, is a multi-part interdisciplinary research that has surfaced amidst the overlapping contexts of climate crisis, threatened ocean ecosystems, and challenges to scientific expertise. In addition to numerous awards and fellowships, her work has been exhibited at institutions such as the Museum of Modern Art, Guggenheim Museum, New Museum, M+ Museum in Hong Kong, and Moderna Museet in Stockholm, Sweden. She teaches at the University of Southern California in Los Angeles, CA.

DAVID KELLEY is an artist working with photography, video, and installation. His recent projects draw attention to the effects of global capitalism, resource extraction, and shifting physical and political landscapes. Influenced by a range of visual traditions, Kelley draws upon elements of experimental documentary, ethnography, performance, and avant-garde cinema. By working at the intersection of these strategies, he encourages an understanding of his subjects that is simultaneously direct and speculative.

His work has been shown in galleries and museums nationally and internationally. Recent exhibitions include the Rencontres Internationales Paris/Berlin, Museum of Modern Art in New York, and Fotofest Biennial, Houston. Other exhibitions include Commonwealth and Council in Los Angeles, The Bank in Shanghai, the de Cordova Biennial in Boston, BAK in Utrecht, MAAP space in Australia, and the Jim Thompson Art Center in Bangkok.

Kelley received a Master of Fine Art from the University of California, Irvine, and was a 2010-11 resident at the Whitney Museum of American Art Independent Study Program. He is currently based in Los Angeles, California, and is an Associate Professor of the Practice of Fine Arts at University of Southern California.

ELIZABETH DELOUGHREY is a professor in the English Department and the Institute of the Environment and Sustainability at UCLA who teaches postcolonial and Indigenous literature courses on the environment, globalization, critical ocean studies, and the Anthropocene and climate change, with a focus on the Caribbean and Pacific Islands (Oceania). She is the author of Routes and Roots: Navigating Caribbean and Pacific Literatures (U of Hawai`i Press, 2007), and Allegories of the Anthropocene (Duke UP, 2019), which examines climate change and empire in the literary and visual arts. She is co-editor of the volumes Caribbean Literature and the Environment: Between Nature and Culture (Virginia UP, 2005); Postcolonial Ecologies: Literatures of the Environment (Oxford UP, 2011); and Global Ecologies and the Environmental Humanities: Postcolonial Approaches (Routledge, 2015) and of numerous journal issues on critical ocean, island and militarism studies. Her scholarship has been supported by institutions such as the American Council of Learned Societies, National Endowment for the Humanities, the Rockefeller Foundation, the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation, Fulbright New Zealand, the Rachel Carson Center (LMU, Munich), the UC Humanities Research Institute, and the Cornell Society for the Humanities. Most recently she was awarded a John Simon Guggenheim Foundation Fellowship (2021-22).

Student Participants

* (listed in alphabetical order of their last names)

Marisol Villela Balderrama is a Ph.D. candidate in the Department of History of Art and Architecture at the University of Pittsburgh. Her research explores the art forms at the crossroads of East Asia and Latin America. Before moving to the US, she completed a four-year MA program at the China Academy of Art in Hangzhou. Her doctoral dissertation examines the Chilean artist José Venturelli’s mural and print production in China, Chile, East Germany, and Cuba and the cultural bridges he helped build in the postwar period across what was then known as the Third World. She has taught at the Wuhan University and the Tecnológico de Monterrey and has research and curatorial experience at the MoMA and the Bilbao Fine Arts Museum, and her work has been published in the journal Art History. Her work also engages with emerging US Latinx communities, the US-Mexico borderlands, and transnational socialist networks.

Abigail Berry is a PhD Candidate in the Department of Art History at UCLA. Her research at the PhD level, under the direction of Dr. Meredith Cohen, focuses on the proliferation of Brick Gothic architecture in northern Europe during the thirteenth and fourteenth centuries. Abigail has received support from the Social Science and Humanities Research Council (2022-2025) and the Diane C. Brouillette (2022-23) fellowship for her dissertation tentatively titled “Brick Gothic Architecture and the Hanseatic League.” Prior to coming to UCLA, Abigail completed her Social Science and Humanities Research Council (2018-2019) and Ontario Graduate Scholarship (2019-2020) funded Master’s degree at Queen’s University in Canada, writing on image processing for art historical investigations. Although her research focuses on architecture, Abigail has also published on medieval manuscripts and worked closely with conservators on digital art conservation.

Carolyn Hauk is a Direct PhD student in Art History at the University of Delaware, studying nineteenth-century American art. Her current research explores nineteenth-century representations of Mississippi floods in American prints, Black ecologies, and resistance to plantation extractive regimes. This year, she is serving as the Graduate Research Assistant for UD’s University Museums, co-curating an exhibition on the artwork of the late professor emeritus and founder of UD’s Black American Studies program James E. Newton. She recently contributed to an episode on the Smithsonian’s podcast channel Sidedoor where she discusses her research on the profiles of New Orleanian and Cuban sitters in William Bache’s ledger book dating to the early nineteenth century. She has worked with the National Gallery of Art, the Smithsonian’s National Portrait Gallery, and the Advisory Council on Historic Preservation. Hauk graduated summa cum laude from Gettysburg College, earning her BA in Art History and History in 2021.

Elizabeth Keto is a PhD candidate in the History of Art department at Yale University. Her dissertation, “Reconstruction’s Objects: Art in the United States South, 1861-1900,” focuses on aesthetics, material culture, and politics in late nineteenth-century America. Her research interests more broadly include landscape, ecology, and empire, as well as the early history of photography and the intersections between scientific and visual cultures. She has presented work at the College Art Association annual conference, Rutgers University, the University of Georgia, and elsewhere. She was the recipient of a 2018 Marshall Scholarship, and she holds master’s degrees in the history of art and in curating from The Courtauld Institute of Art in London. Her professional experiences include work at the Museum of Modern Art and the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York and Tate Britain and the Whitechapel Gallery in London.

Noah Michaud is a first-year PhD student in the History of Art at Yale University. His research explores the visual, material, and mercantile exchanges between northern Italy, especially the Republic of Venice, and sub-Saharan Africa in the early modern era. More broadly, it engages representations in text and image of Africa, Africans, and the slave trades; the historiography of African art, architecture, and nature; collecting, colonialism, and repatriation; sub-Saharan African perceptions of Mediterranean Europe and Europeans, and Venetian print culture. His professional aspirations include scholar, public intellectual, and art lawyer with expertise in African antiquities restitution, cultural heritage preservation, and international partnerships. Noah received his B.A. summa cum laude from Duke University in 2021, majoring with distinction in Art History with a Concentration in Museum Theory and Practice. Most recently (2023), he received his M.A. in art history from the University of Florida.

Johanna Middleton (she/her) is an educator-artist-scholar with a passion for telling stories and facilitating healing spaces for others to tell their stories and engage in brave spaces for dialogue across difference. Her work focuses on the applications of storytelling within a lineage of Black feminist performance pedagogy and asks how we can learn and unlearn through the stories that we tell with and about our bodies. Johanna received her BA in Theatre at Northwestern and her MA in Communication Studies (Performance Studies focus) at Louisiana State University. She is currently a 2nd year PhD student in Performance Studies at Northwestern. Her scholarly work has been published in Storytelling, Self, and Society and Liminalities.

Hande Sever is a research-based artist and scholar from Istanbul, Turkey. Her research concerns theories of sovereignty and biopolitics with a focus on the role of arts in resistance practices from West Asia. Her areas of specialty include the visual cultures of modern West Asia and its diasporas, colonial studies and traditions of materialist thought. Her scholarship has been published in leading museums’ peer-reviewed journals and special issues, including Stedelijk Museum’s Stedelijk Studies, The Art Institute of Chicago’s special volume Perspectives on In/tability, and the J. Paul Getty Museum’s Getty Research Journal, among others. Her works have been supported with grants from the Félix González-Torres Foundation, California Arts Council, Getty Foundation, Henry Luce Foundation, Russell Foundation and Allianz Foundation.

Shariq Shah is an interdisciplinary designer, researcher, and Master’s candidate at the Harvard Graduate School of Design. His scholarly, teaching, and design work addresses issues of infrastructural ecologies, disaster migration, and post-colonial landscapes across the geographies of South Asia and the Southeastern United States. Such research investigations have culminated in text and image publications in STRELKA and Scroll India. His independent research projects, concerning post-petroleum futures, urban disaster imaginaries, and ancient ecological kinships, have been supported by grants from the Harvard Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study, Harvard Urban Planning and Design, and Carnegie Mellon SoA. Shariq earned his Bachelor of Architecture from the College of Fine Arts at Carnegie Mellon University.
